social_posts.post_text:
It’s hard to think of reproach, hatred and backlash as a blessing, but it’s true. If you are a follower of Jesus, boldly sharing the gospel and standing on the truth of God’s Word in this dark generation, you will face persecution of some kind.

Sadly, many strive to live a life of avoidance. Love somehow is preached as passivity and standing for truth becomes too controversial for their standard. They become afraid of disagreements and upsetting the masses, which ultimately lures them into a life of people-pleasing and bowing to a culture that will bully every word they try to speak. A change of perspective is needed.

Instead of avoiding persecution and backlash, we need to accept it and expect it as a response that comes with the territory of a believer. Why do we live afraid of something that we are told is a blessing? Probably because we know it’s not easy. But to suffer for the glory of God is an honor, and the moment we begin to look at it that way, we will embrace it with the strength of the Lord. No matter what comes our way. 

•1Peter 4:12-16//  Beloved, do not think it strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened to you; but rejoice to the extent that you partake of Christ’s sufferings, that when His glory is revealed, you may also be glad with exceeding joy. If you are reproached for the name of Christ, blessed are you, for the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you. On their part He is blasphemed, but on your part He is glorified. But let none of you suffer as a murderer, a thief, an evildoer, or as a busybody in other people’s matters. Yet if anyone suffers as a Christian, let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God in this matter.

Just a reminder to stay focused on what truly matters.

•Psalm 62:8- Trust in him at all times, O people; pour out your heart before him; God is a refuge for us. Selah

•Ephesians 2:4-6// But God, being rich in mercy, because of the great love with which he loved us, even when we were dead in our trespasses, made us alive together with Christ—by grace you have been saved— and raised us up with him and seated us with him in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus.

•John 10:10-11//The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy. I came that they may have life and have it abundantly. I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.

•John 14:21- Whoever has my commandments and keeps them, he it is who loves me. And he who loves me will be loved by my Father, and I will love him and manifest myself to him.”

Jesus didn’t deceive us when we made the decision to follow Him. We knew this walk wouldn’t be easy. But oh, is it infinitely worth it.

•John 15:18-21// If the world hates you, you know that it hated Me before it hated you. If you were of the world, the world would love its own. Yet because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you. Remember the word that I said to you, ‘A servant is not greater than his master.’ If they persecuted Me, they will also persecute you. If they kept My word, they will keep yours also. But all these things they will do to you for My name’s sake, because they do not know Him who sent Me.

It’s very easy to give way to anxiety and worry. This is why I am thankful for 2Corinthians 10:3-6.

“For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war according to the flesh. For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal but mighty in God for pulling down strongholds, casting down arguments and every high thing that exalts itself against the knowledge of God, bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ, and being ready to punish all disobedience when your obedience is fulfilled.”

Do you know what sticks out to me the most in the select text? “...bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ.”

God’s Word is our remedy. It’s the driving force that serves as a deterrent to the enemy and it is the power behind every promise God has ever given.

Here are some of my go-to scriptures that I often stand upon in regards to fear, anxiety and worry. Enjoy💛

•2Timothy 1:7 - For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power and of love and of a sound mind.

•Psalm 34:4 - I sought the Lord, and He heard me, And delivered me from all my fears.

•Isaiah 41:10 - Fear not, for I am with you; Be not dismayed, for I am your God. I will strengthen you, Yes, I will help you, I will uphold you with My righteous right hand.’

•Psalm 56:3-4 // Whenever I am afraid, I will trust in You. In God (I will praise His word), In God I have put my trust; I will not fear. What can flesh do to me?

•John 14:27 - Peace I leave with you, My peace I give to you; not as the world gives do I give to you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.

•1Peter 5:6-7 // Therefore humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due time, casting all your care upon Him, for He cares for you.

•Philippians 4:6-7// Be anxious for nothing, but in everything by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God; and the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.

Wisdom is needed. Let’s look at James 1:5 real quick...

“If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally and without reproach, and it will be given to him.”

God gives wisdom when we recognize we are lacking wisdom then graciously ask Him for more. This is so encouraging to me because then it says that God gives wisdom liberally! Freely! Without reproach! How generous and KIND!

Let’s all take a moment to identify this need in our lives and ask God for more wisdom. This will be mandatory in the days ahead, especially in the arena of discerning what to listen to and what to ignore.

•James 3:13- Who is wise and understanding among you? By his good conduct let him show his works in the meekness of wisdom.

•James 3:17- But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, open to reason, full of mercy and good fruits, impartial and sincere.

•Proverbs 1:7- The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction.

•Ephesians 5:15-17// Look carefully then how you walk, not as unwise but as wise, making the best use of the time, because the days are evil. Therefore do not be foolish, but understand what the will of the Lord is.

•Proverbs 2:6- For the Lord gives wisdom; from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.

•Proverbs 11:2- When pride comes, then comes disgrace, but with the humble is wisdom.

If a little leaven leavens the whole lump of dough and a mustard seed of faith is powerful enough to move a mountain…then nothing is “too small” or insignificant to make an impact in our lives. Good or bad…it all matters. I’ll just leave it at that for those who have ears to hear today.

•Galatians 6:7- Do not be deceived: God is not mocked, for whatever one sows, that will he also reap.

•Matthew 6:22-23// The eye is the lamp of the body. So, if your eye is healthy, your whole body will be full of light, but if your eye is bad, your whole body will be full of darkness. If then the light in you is darkness, how great is the darkness!

•Philippians 4:8- Finally, brothers, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is just, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is commendable, if there is any excellence, if there is anything worthy of praise, think about these things.

•1John 2:15-17// Do not love the world or the things in the world. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him. For all that is in the world—the desires of the flesh and the desires of the eyes and pride in possessions—is not from the Father but is from the world. And the world is passing away along with its desires, but whoever does the will of God abides forever.

•Psalm 101:2-4// I will ponder the way that is blameless. Oh when will you come to me? I will walk with integrity of heart within my house; I will not set before my eyes anything that is worthless. I hate the work of those who fall away; it shall not cling to me. A perverse heart shall be far from me; I will know nothing of evil.

•Ephesians 5:11- Take no part in the unfruitful works of darkness, but instead expose them.

•Proverbs 4:23- Keep your heart with all vigilance, for from it flow the springs of life.

•1Corinthians 10:31- So, whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do all to the glory of God.

Because He shall. We must always live a life of eager expectancy!

•Matthew 24:44- Therefore you also must be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.

•Matthew 24:36- “But concerning that day and hour no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, nor the Son, but the Father only.”

•Revelation 1:7- Behold, he is coming with the clouds, and every eye will see him, even those who pierced him, and all tribes of the earth will wail on account of him. Even so. Amen.

•1Thessalonians 14:16-17// For the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a cry of command, with the voice of an archangel, and with the sound of the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first. Then we who are alive, who are left, will be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air, and so we will always be with the Lord.

I am choosing the way of Jesus. Every single time.

•John 8:31-32// So Jesus said to the Jews who had believed in him, “If you abide in my word, you are truly my disciples, and you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.”

•John 14:6- Jesus said to him, “I am the way, and the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.

•John 16:13- However, when He, the Spirit of truth, has come, He will guide you into all truth; for He will not speak on His own authority, but whatever He hears He will speak; and He will tell you things to come.

When will we ever learn that it’s infinitely more rewarding to pursue God and His perfect will than anything else in life?

Although we are often prone to wandering, may we always be reminded that this world can offer us nothing good outside of Jesus. That’s just the reality. 

With many fruitless distractions surrounding us day by day, I always make it a point to keep my eyes on Jesus and the eternity that has been set before us. It’s my perspective shifter. It pulls me back from chasing momentary satisfaction and it keeps me focused during momentary affliction.

I want God’s perfect will for my life.

No matter what that looks like, I’m entirely sold out to His mandate and cause. 

Just thinking out loud today💛

•Matthew 16:24-28// Then Jesus said to His disciples, “If anyone desires to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow Me. For whoever desires to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for My sake will find it. For what profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own soul? Or what will a man give in exchange for his soul? For the Son of Man will come in the glory of His Father with His angels, and then He will reward each according to his works. Assuredly, I say to you, there are some standing here who shall not taste death till they see the Son of Man coming in His kingdom.”

In Matthew 11, John the Baptist had been wrongfully imprisoned and in his current state of possible concern, he set a few of his followers out to ask Jesus a question; “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”

Jesus answered and told the disciples to tell John all that they had seen and heard. Then in verse 6, He sent them away with an important declaration;
“And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”

Offense can attractively present itself as a reasonable response when hurt is present. Jesus understood this and He was aware of the schemes of the devil.

Consider this: John the Baptist is sitting in prison and he is going to be executed. He probably didn’t think his 6 month ministry as a forerunner for the Messiah was going to end like this. How easy it would be to fall into confusion and doubt everything he stood for...including Jesus.

John and his disciples had to be open to God’s unfolding plan despite it not matching their expectations. The good news is; the kindness of Jesus reached out with understanding and immediately combated the possibility for offense.

“Blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”

Hurt happens. Things won’t go as planned. People will do things and it will cause pain. I’m not excusing bad behavior, but I am inviting you to be set free. Living offended is a choice. Hear me please; LIVING OFFENDED IS A CHOICE. It’s false justice. It’s also bait given by the enemy. Because if the enemy can grab ahold of your hurt, he will transition it to offense. And if that offense sits long enough, it will soon sour into bitterness.

Friend, please do not live in a constant state of offense. Do not live offended by man nor by Christ. Attend to the wounds in your life, pray and release this to God. Ask Him for the help you need to let go and forgive. Remember: Forgiveness isn’t saying the offense or offender is right; it’s saying that what Jesus did on the cross is right.

In every season, no matter what it looks like, the glory belongs to God alone!

•Philippians 4:6-7// Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.

•Philippians 4:12-14// I know how to be brought low, and I know how to abound. In any and every circumstance, I have learned the secret of facing plenty and hunger, abundance and need. I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

•Psalm 118:5- I called upon the LORD in distress: the LORD answered me, and set me in a large place.

•James 1:17- Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights with whom there is no variation or shadow due to change.

•Luke 12:24- Consider the ravens: they neither sow nor reap, they have neither storehouse nor barn, and yet God feeds them. Of how much more value are you than the birds!

•2Corinthians 9:8- And God is able to make all grace abound to you, so that having all sufficiency in all things at all times, you may abound in every good work.

•Hebrews 11:6- And without faith it is impossible to please him, for whoever would draw near to God must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who seek him.

•Psalm 84:11- For the Lord God is a sun and shield; the Lord bestows favor and honor. No good thing does he withhold from those who walk uprightly.

The bottom line to my life.

•1John 2:16-17// And the world is passing away along with its desires, but whoever does the will of God abides forever.

•Philippians 4:19- And my God will supply every need of yours according to his riches in glory in Christ Jesus.

•Proverbs 19:21- Many are the plans in the mind of a man, but it is the purpose of the Lord that will stand.

I decided a long time ago that I cannot be “moved” by money. Whether we have a little or a lot, I choose to remain content. I can be thankful for it, I will be a good steward of it, I will bless others with it, but I won’t be moved by it.

So, with that said, I was in prayer today and I want to encourage you to be vigilant. 

You and I have a greater calling than trying to obtain everything under the sun. We must refuse to be swept up in materialism. See, money will enslave us IF we attach our emotions and value to it’s quantity. It says in the Word that the LOVE of money is the ROOT of ALL evil. Really think about that. We don’t have time to love something that will only enslave us. 

TRUE peace, joy, security and contentment is found in Jesus alone. It cannot be found in earthly things that are here today and gone tomorrow.

I know you know that, but just felt led to put the reminder out there anyway.

•Hebrews 13:5- Keep your life free from love of money, and be content with what you have, for he has said, “I will never leave you nor forsake you.”

•Philippians 4:11-13// Not that I speak in regard to need, for I have learned in whatever state I am, to be content: I know how to be abased, and I know how to abound. Everywhere and in all things I have learned both to be full and to be hungry, both to abound and to suffer need. I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.

I hope the answer is yes. This is the lifestyle of faithful obedience and having a servant’s heart.

•Colossians 3:23-24// Whatever you do, work heartily, as for the Lord and not for men, knowing that from the Lord you will receive the inheritance as your reward. You are serving the Lord Christ.

•1Samuel 12:24- Only fear the Lord and serve him faithfully with all your heart. For consider what great things he has done for you.

There are a lot of voices saying a lot of different things now a days. Please don’t allow just anyone to speak into your life.

Are they following God?
Are they listening to God?
Are they obedient to God?
Are they in agreement with God's Word?

These are the 4 questions I always ask myself when I’m offered advice or opinions on how I should live my life. Then from there, even if they ARE a believer, I STILL proceed in discernment and rely upon the Holy Spirit.

Because truthfully, everything you give an ear to needs to be rooted and grounded in the Word of God. My friend, you cannot afford to settle for anything less. This isn’t about being harsh, this is about using wisdom.💛

•John 16:13- When the Spirit of truth comes, he will guide you into all the truth, for he will not speak on his own authority, but whatever he hears he will speak, and he will declare to you the things that are to come.

•Colossians 2:8- See to it that no one takes you captive by philosophy and empty deceit, according to human tradition, according to the elemental spirits of the world, and not according to Christ.

•Psalm 119:160- The sum of your word is truth, and every one of your righteous rules endures forever.

•Psalm 86:11- Teach me your way, O Lord, that I may walk in your truth; unite my heart to fear your name.

•John 14:17- Even the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees him nor knows him. You know him, for he dwells with you and will be in you.

•1John 4:1- Beloved, do not believe every spirit, but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, for many false prophets have gone out into the world.

Lately, I’ve seen a lot of patronizing and passive aggressive talk being passed off as “ministry”, and it has stirred something up inside of me that I can’t ignore. 

Listen, I get it. You have my solidarity in regards to refusing to conform and comply to worldly corruption. But we have to use wisdom. Zeal is a wonderful thing. Being passionate about something is a driving force that can bring about impactful results. But zeal and passion can turn a good thing into a bad thing if it isn’t laid down in submission before the Lord.

Think about Peter cutting off the ear of Malchus for arresting Jesus, or James and John wanting Jesus to call down fire on the Samaritan village for not receiving Him. They wanted to defend truth but not in an opportune way.

We are living in a corrupt era filled with lies, deceit and perversion. Nothing new under the sun, I know, but wickedness has shape-shifted and taken on a different form that is unfamiliar in this generation. Because of this, many of us want to speak up and shine our light in this darkness. AS WE SHOULD! 

But…we need to do so under the Lordship of Jesus Christ. He is our example.

This is about the heart. It’s about our “why”. And at the end of the day, our “why” is to glorify God and point others to Christ. 

Be bold. Declare truth. Expose the unfruitful works of darkness. Refute lies by sharing  accurate information. But be considerate. Be patient with others. Be gentle and wise. Set boundaries when you need to. And above all, preach the Gospel to every living creature.

•1Peter 3:15- But in your hearts honor Christ the Lord as holy, always being prepared to make a defense to anyone who asks you for a reason for the hope that is in you; yet do it with gentleness and respect.

If you’ve been around my page over the last few years, you also know that I never usually promote companies or products. All have contained such special and unique items that I have kept around our home or gifted to family and friends.

Ps. Looking at picture 8, the table runner in Hebrew is one of my absolute favorites in this box. It says, “Blessed are you, our God, who feeds the entire world through Your goodness, with kindness and graciousness”

Living set apart isn’t merely a suggestion, it’s the fruit of being a follower of Jesus. You are not of this world, my friend. Your standard is the gospel and your bottom line is the Word of God. Stand strong in the Lord and in the power of His might (Ephesians 6:10). 

•2Timothy 2:15- Be diligent to present yourself approved to God, a worker who does not need to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth.

•Romans 12:2- Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect.

•1Peter 2:9- But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for his own possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.

•John 17:15-18// I do not ask that you take them out of the world, but that you keep them from the evil one. They are not of the world, just as I am not of the world. Sanctify them in the truth; your word is truth. As you sent me into the world, so I have sent them into the world.

•John 15:19- If you were of the world, the world would love you as its own; but because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.

Never underestimate the ministry found within the day-to-day tasks. Especially the areas that are under heavy attack by wickedness. 

Whether you are hosting a small Bible study, starting an online ministry to reach others, witnessing to people at your school or work, encouraging a loved one who needs hope, working 40+ hours a week to provide for your family, writing music or blogs that honor God, starting a business with biblical principals, serving at your local church, taking care of your family and raising little warriors for the Lord; please never underestimate the impact of what you are doing simply because it’s not packaged in the flashy “ministry” trimmings of national and global success.

Simply put, what you are doing for the Kingdom of God matters. Everything you do unto the Lord matters. And you don’t have to measure yourself on some worldly grand scale to ensure your success.

Success is obedience to God. Success is being faithful with what God has given you. That’s true success. 

Nothing is overlooked and nothing is wasted.

Continue on, friend.

•Colossians 3:23-24// Whatever you do, work heartily, as for the Lord and not for men, knowing that from the Lord you will receive the inheritance as your reward. You are serving the Lord Christ.

•1Corinthians 15:58- Therefore, my beloved brothers, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that in the Lord your labor is not in vain.

A timeless bottom line to live by. Easy? Not at all, but a goal filled with freedom and joy that we should fix our eyes on day by day.

•2 Corinthians 5:20- Therefore, we are ambassadors for Christ, God making his appeal through us. We implore you on behalf of Christ, be reconciled to God.

•1Peter 2:9- But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for his own possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.

•Colossians 3:17- And whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through him.

•1Peter 2:1-5// So put away all malice and all deceit and hypocrisy and envy and all slander. Like newborn infants, long for the pure spiritual milk, that by it you may grow up into salvation— if indeed you have tasted that the Lord is good. As you come to him, a living stone rejected by men but in the sight of God chosen and precious, you yourselves like living stones are being built up as a spiritual house, to be a holy priesthood, to offer spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.

I’m reading out of Mark 8 today and verse 38 stuck out to me. Jesus provides a warning of those who are ashamed of Him and His Words in an adulterous and sinful generation. 

I see this everyday. Unbelievablers and especially even Christians who think God’s Word is too harsh, too hard hitting, too “out-of-date” to reach this sinful generation, so they try to deconstruct and manipulate the Bible to support what *they* think is easier to accept. They steer clear from speaking on certain controversial topics of wildly accepted sin because they love social acceptance rather than their faithfulness to God. Too harsh? Let’s take a look at Mark 8:38 in its entirety to see what Jesus has to say about it:

“For whoever is ashamed of Me and My words in this adulterous and sinful generation, of him the Son of Man also will be ashamed when He comes in the glory of His Father with the holy angels.”

Three words: LOUD AND CLEAR.

Jesus made this point absolutely loud and clear and there’s no way to try and steer around it.

Are we ashamed of what Jesus has spoken because we know it is offensive to those who are perishing or living a luke-warm Christianity? Are we afraid to stand on the Word of God in this adulterous and sinful generation?

Friends, either we are boldly standing up for the Gospel or we are ashamed of the Gospel. Either we pick up our cross and follow Jesus or we reject the Word and deny Jesus. 

As we know, there is no middle ground nor any fence to sit on. Choose this day whom you will serve.

•Romans 1:16- For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.

Go to God first. That’s it. That’s the message. 

Cultivating this standard in my life has been a huge game changer. It has been the defining choice that has led to clarity, direction and peace. All of which can only come from God. 

When I’m in need of guidance.
When I have to make a decision.
When I need encouragement.
When I feel overwhelmed.
When anxiety tries to creep in.

I open up my Bible to see what God has to say about it. I quiet myself before the Lord to share my heart with Him. 

He created me; He holds the wisdom and knowledge. Does anyone know better than Him?

My friend, once your heart is established on this, once you seek Him first, you’ll have the peace to then reach out to other resources for advice, support or prayer.

But go to Him first. Always Him first.

•Matthew 6:33- But seek first the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.

•Romans 8:5- For those who live according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit set their minds on the things of the Spirit.

•Jeremiah 32:27- Behold, I am the LORD, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?

I’m 36 today🎉

Some people despise birthdays as they grow older. Especially in the type of society we are living in today, hiding your age is the norm, growing old is considered a burden, and marketing is geared toward enhancing youth rather than embracing the process of aging.

I choose to be thankful. 

Thankful to God that He has blessed me with another year to serve Him. Thankful to God for another year to serve my husband and my son. Thankful to God for the wonderful friends and family I have in my life. Thankful for all things and in all circumstances.

I also have immense gratitude for the community I’ve found here on social media with like-minded believers. I’ve made some life-long friends due to this space, and I’m thankful for everyone here who has always been so supportive, kind, and generous to my family and I. It genuinely means more to me than you’ll ever know.

Love y’all 💛

•Psalm 106:1- Praise the Lord! Oh give thanks to the Lord, for he is good, for his steadfast love endures forever!

•1Thessalonians 5:16-18// Rejoice always, pray without ceasing, give thanks in all circumstances; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you.

•Psalm 28:7- The Lord is my strength and my shield; in him my heart trusts, and I am helped; my heart exults, and with my song I give thanks to him.

I’ve said this before, but scrolling through social media today and seeing some posts has given me the unction to share again. Just a friendly reminder for today and all the days ahead.

•Proverbs 13:3- Whoever guards his mouth preserves his life; he who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.

•Matthew 12:36-37// I tell you, on the day of judgment people will give account for every careless word they speak, for by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned.”

•Proverbs 18:21- Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruits.

•Proverbs 17:27- He who has knowledge spares his words, and a man of understanding is of a calm spirit.

O Holy Night has been running through my mind all day. Specifically this part:

“Till He appeared and the soul felt its worth.
A thrill of hope, the weary world rejoices,
For yonder breaks a new and glorious morn.”

Think about that. “A thrill of hope, the weary world rejoices.”

Oh, how I long to see this weary world rejoice, a second time, at the return of Jesus Christ. His birth is something to be celebrated. His death and resurrection is something to be celebrated. And His return shall be the glorious grand finale that we will celebrate for all eternity.

For every knee shall bow and every tongue shall confess Jesus Christ as Lord to the glory of God the Father.

Amen.

•Matthew 1:21- And she will bring forth a Son, and you shall call His name Jesus, for He will save His people from their sins.

social_posts.post_text:
Amen.

•Acts 4:12- And there is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.

•John 14:1-6// Let not your heart be troubled; you believe in God, believe also in Me. In My Father’s house are many mansions; if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you. And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again and receive you to Myself; that where I am, there you may be also. And where I go you know, and the way you know.”

“I delight to do Your will, O my God; Your Law is within my heart.”

My greatest desire in life is to do the will of God. My deepest joy is to obey and also rest in the Living God. And I have come to the conclusion that when you set your life upon this, things will often become difficult. Choosing the will of God for your life is a daily decision. It’s a journey on the narrow path that seems to get more narrow by the day. And as I observe the life of Jesus in scripture, I am reminded that the narrow way is not easy, but infinitely worth every step of obedience.

So, as David declared so passionately, and as Jesus lived so gracefully and prophetically…to delight in doing the will of God is, for us, the fruit of living a life entirely yielded to the Holy Spirit.

You know the routine; new year, new goals, new projects, new opportunities, new plans etc. But I’m inviting you to take a step back for a moment and heed the leading of the Lord.

WHAT IF (and I’m not saying this is for everyone), but WHAT IF God isn’t calling you to automatically sprint into this new year as a busy little bee🐝? What if He is calling you to start 2023 in complete and total REST?

Would you be alright with that? While everyone around you is hitting the gym with their new membership, starting new bible plans, diving into new projects, cultivating new business strategies, would you be comfortable with the fact that God is just calling you to lean into His leading and simply rest? 

If the thought of that makes you anxious, we may be onto something here, because rest should never make you anxious. 

Here’s my encouragement: you don’t need to be busy to be fruitful. You don’t need to keep up with everyone else to feel accomplished. You don’t need to have countless new goals, and “hit the ground running” plans to welcome the new year with wisdom.

Like I said before, this message isn’t for everyone, but I do know it’s for someone. And I pray it resonates. 

If you feel led, take some time to pray and seek the Lord this month. Yes, I said this month. The whole entire month. Let yourself off the hook of trying to fill up your calendar and appear as the woman who “does it all.” 

Life is not a competition.
Success is not a competition.
Marriage is not a competition.
Motherhood is not a competition.
Ministry is not a competition.
Friendship is not a competition.

Rest from all the carnal striving.

Seek the Lord, and if even for a moment, make it a point to rest this year. Because within that rest, you will find more fulfillment in His presence than you ever could in all of your “doing”. Trust me on that one.

Today I found myself entertaining thoughts that were traveling weeks and months ahead to potentially create plans and outcomes for situations that may or may not even happen. Do you know what this produced? Worry and anxiety.

Amy. Be anxious for nothing. 

I had to stop myself, take a deep breath and verbally say out loud, “I’m sorry, God. I trust that You are able.”

Why is it sometimes so easy to immediately fret and worry, when we readily have the Word of God to remind us of His timeless Truth? 

Maybe it’s just me, but I have to remind myself, DAILY, that He is God…I am not…He knows best…I do not.

That’s why I am so dearly fond of this wise quote by Elisabeth Elliot. 

“Today is mine. Tomorrow is none of my business. If I peer anxiously into the fog of the future, I will strain my spiritual eyes so that I will not see clearly what is required of me now.”

Did you catch those crucial last words? 

“…that I will not see clearly what is required of me now.”

Friends, I simply do not want to live distracted by the worries of destination addiction. 

Always living in a constant state of mind that is desperately trying to attain the outcome of a future event, while missing what God is asking of me today.

Far be it from me, Lord. 
I need to do better in this area.
I’m so thankful for His grace. 

If you find that this resonates with you as well, I’m glad you now know that you’re not alone.

Here are some scriptures I’ve been meditating on tonight. I pray they bring you the peace that they have brought me.

•Philippians 4:6-7// Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.

•Matthew 6:27- And which of you by being anxious can add a single hour to his span of life?

•Proverbs 3:5-6// Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and do not lean on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make straight your paths.

•Psalm 94:19- When the cares of my heart are many, your consolations cheer my soul.

People live under a lot of unnecessary pressure simply because they are afraid of disappointing the expectations of others. 

They will agree to things out of fear, compromise convictions to “keep the peace”, live afraid to say “no” to others, and will often times stand down for truth in order to avoid conflict.

But what if I told you that this is actually a form of bondage? It’s called the fear of man. Living in such a way that you want to please others so much that it may actually come before being obedient to God. 

My friend, obedience to God will sometimes mean that you may disappoint the expectations of others. Your “yes” to God will sometimes mean you have to give a “no” to someone else.

God may call you to do some things that people won’t understand. They may push back. Will you allow that to hinder you? Will you care so much to please man that you are willing to displease God?

Hard questions; but this is something we all are faced with in our lives.

The good news is; where we are weak, He is strong. If you find yourself unwillingly falling into this cycle-trap of people-pleasing and fearing man, pray and ask God where the root of this is tied to. Often times, it is linked to past trauma and unresolved coping mechanisms learned throughout life. He is WILLING and ABLE to break these barriers in our lives, but WE must be WILLING and ABLE to hand these areas over to His Lordship and leading.

Living to please God and not man must be a foundation in all of our lives. It may not be easy, and the process may be hard, but the reward is freedom...and nothing is more important than that.

•1Thessalonians 2:4-  But just as we have been approved by God to be entrusted with the gospel, so we speak, not to please man, but to please God who tests our hearts.

•Galatians 1:10- For am I now seeking the approval of man, or of God? Or am I trying to please man? If I were still trying to please man, I would not be a servant of Christ.

•Romans 8:8- Those who are in the flesh cannot please God.

I love the following lyrics by Keith & Melody Green…

“Thank You Lord for being patient with me. For it’s so hard to see when my eyes are on me.”

How easy it is to fall into the trap of self-glorification. 

The enemy enjoys to overplay his hand in this area. He is continually hard at work to entice us in keeping an obsessive eye on ourselves, craving praise and adoration, basing high importance merely on the outward appearance, being seen and well known, being applauded and validated by others, and appearing successful and perfect.

These toxic concepts are always presented as subtle thoughts that, acted upon, aggressively spin into idols that soon become more valuable than pursuing the things of the Spirit and simply living free in the acceptance and love of Jesus.

My reminder is simple today: take inventory of what has captured your attention. What glorifies the flesh is ultimately not glorifying God.

It is important to note I am not insinuating that giving honor to others or having success is wrong. Romans 12:10 says to outdo one another in showing honor. But when done in the biblically accurate way, this honor will in return, give glory to God instead of ourselves. That is the key.

The amazing truth is, we are new creations in Christ Jesus and we are no longer of this world. We do not adhere to worldly principles, ideologies, concepts and desires. Those things are dead to us and have been crucified with the flesh. Now; we are in this world living to glorify God, preach the Gospel, and shine the truth of His Word wherever we go. This is our mandate, our bottom line and our focal point.

If you find yourself often struggling in these areas, my advice is simple: look to the cross and remember what we are all deserving of apart from Jesus. This always helps me to combat pride and to keep my eyes on what truly matters.

I know I’ve said this before, but at the risk of sounding like a broken record, I’m genuinely asking: has the enemy gained a foothold in this area?

Speaking from experience, it’s good to take inventory of your life and evaluate where you are investing your time.

Ok, more questions…

Are you reading your Bible? Have you given some time to spend with God? Do you pray and intercede? Are you growing in Christ and in the knowledge of the Holy One? (2Peter 3:18)

This isn’t legalism; this is about spiritual maturity and growing in the Lord during an era where evil is now called good, and good is now called evil. This is the greatest investment you can make on earth.

No condemnation. No need to get offended. If you find yourself in need of slightly shifting your time and priorities, well then, make the change right now.

Whether you work on location or at home, currently unemployed, constantly taking care of your children, whether you’re retired or in a season of transition...I’m telling you...your schedule CAN be reordered to prioritize the Lord. 

And please don’t get caught up in the amount of “time spent”. This is where many people get discouraged and think that reading for 10-15 minutes on their busiest day isn’t enough, so they scrap their whole plan to read the Bible entirely. 

Sometimes it’s as easy as setting aside your phone, tablet or laptop and simply picking up your Bible. Start there. 

Enjoy this time with Him.

When I think of Jospeh in the Old Testament, I think of his profound humility.

If Jospeh’s jealous brothers had not sold him to traders, to then be sold to Potiphar, to then be wrongfully accused and put into prison, to then go from the prison to the palace....I wonder how Jospeh would’ve gotten to be second in command to pharaoh? 

God worked it all for good, didn’t He?

God used the mistreatment of others to accompany His plans for the future leadership He had installed into Joseph. He also used the mistreatment of others to refine the character of Jospeh.

It all had a purpose. 

The end result? Jospeh became a trustworthy leader, second in command to Pharaoh. But to me, the most amazing part of his story is the humility and grace that Joseph showed towards his brothers who rejected him and meant evil toward him.

•Genesis 50:20- As for you, you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good in order to bring about this present result, to save many lives.

God’s plan for Joseph far exceeded Jospeh. This was just a small piece in a much larger puzzle, so to speak, that was used to prepare an entire nation for plenty and for famine.

You know; I’m not sure how long it took Jospeh to fully forgive his brothers for what they had done to him. He sure did have a lot of time to process it all while wrongfully sitting in prison.

But by looking at the way the scriptures continuously mention that God was with Jospeh, something tells me he forgave and showed grace because he walked in that type of closeness with God.

When you’ve been shown kindness and grace, and when you walk in the Lord’s favor, it cultivates compassion in you toward others. Yes, even those who have dealt unfairly with you.

God meant it all for good.

And there’s no better story than when He receives the glory.

There are so many thoughts I want to share. How do you encapsulate years of prayers, desires and longings of the heart into a caption accompanied by photos? No matter what I type, words do not bring sufficiency to the gratitude I have for what God has done in my life, and within my family.

I’ve always wanted twins, and this desire started very young. My dad is an identical twin, and growing up watching the close relationship he has with his brother always left me desiring that special bond for my children someday. 

So I prayed. 

I’ve prayed many prayers for children. God graciously gave us Galilee.

I prayed many prayers for twins. Did I have faith it would happen? Sometimes. But to be completely honest, my faith was very small. 

Infertility and loss can drastically change the way you look at things. If you’re not careful, the pain and trauma can create a sort of lens, where you view things in a way that God never intended. The potential to become cynical, bitter, jealous, hopeless, fearful, and angry is quite real, and it takes intentional prayer to stay out of that depressive mindset despite the circumstances. I have many friends who have walked this road and know exactly what I’m talking about. 

But, nevertheless, I prayed for what I deeply desired, but more importantly, I prayed above all else for *God’s will* to be accomplished in my life. At the end of the day, I want what He wants for me, because with or without children…with or without twins, He knows what is best. I truly have built my life upon that. 

Why He decided to gift us with twins, I’ll never know. He gives and He takes away; I’ve experienced both. There’s nothing “good, perfect, and deserving” about us that would persuade Him into doing so. There’s no specific prayers or words we offered. It’s just His goodness, kindness, mercy and sovereignty that made a way. His will is always best, whether it matches our heart’s desires or not.

There’s so much more I want to share about all of this, but I’ll end it here for now. Glory to God for what He has done💛 

📸 @amandatallonphoto

Despite popular belief, “pray for your enemies”, is not a passive aggressive phrase to appear self-righteous. It’s a declaration from Jesus, and if anyone had the right to speak on this matter, it would be Him.

During the ministry of Jesus, He was often wildly misunderstood. As a matter of fact, a group of religious men known as the Pharisees and Sadducees would often follow His travel plans to attend His gatherings all for one purpose: to try and catch Him in some sort of error or hypocrisy (Matthew 22:15, Mark 12:13). They once even accused Him of working with the ruler of demons, Beelzebub, to cast out demons (Matthew 12:24). 

Jesus, however perceived their intentions. Yet despite their hatred for Him, Jesus can never be found in a stature of forbidding them to attend where He ministered. Time after time they were given opportunities to look past their religion and instead perceive the new covenant of relationship. But they completely missed it. Their theology had no room for a suffering messiah from Nazareth. They were looking for a prestige King that fit inside of their box of worldly interpretations.

God often does things outside of our understanding, and if we merely judge based upon what we see, we too can be found in error of missing what God is doing in our midst.

I just wanted to take a moment to thank every single person who has reached out over the last week after learning about the death of our twin son. I’ve read every comment and DM. I’ve appreciated every single text and phone call. I’ve been overwhelmed with gratitude for every generous gift that we have received. I’m truly thankful for the support, love and especially the prayers.

Thank you to those who have checked in on my husband and I, almost every single day, even when we didn’t give an immediate response. Thank you for the tremendous outpouring of encouragement and comfort through scripture. Thank you for being understanding of our grief and being supportive of the time we’ve taken away from social media, personal gatherings, etc. The grace we have been shown has made this last week feel not as heavy as I know it could be.

Although my heart is still so sad about our twin son and the grief is still overwhelming at times, the love and support from everyone has helped me more than anyone will ever know. 

I’m planning on possibly being back on social media sometime next week. We’ll see. I miss encouraging and sharing scripture with everyone; it’s one of my most treasured things to do. I pray that through this current trial and tribulation, God will soon allow me to share and speak from a position of transparency that will comfort others who are also having to walk through grief, loss and hardship. 

Grief and gratitude can occupy the same space without disrupting our faith. I’m currently living this. God is sovereign and He is good. I’m so thankful for His love and leadership. 

💛 - Amy

Appointments at the high risk facility are not my favorite. Sitting in the quiet waiting room is not my favorite. Having to receive countless ultrasounds and blood draws to ensure baby and I are safe, is not my favorite. Looking at every ultrasound and seeing them type, “demise of baby A”, is not my favorite. Waiting to see the doctor without knowing how baby B is doing, is not my favorite.

But this is where God has me right now.

Sometimes God’s will requires a certain breaking accompanied by many tears in order to get through to the other side of His purpose. Could He accomplish His plans without the pain? Certainly. But then, I believe, we would miss the opportunity to know Him on an intimate level that seems to sweetly arrive through a certain measure of suffering. 

I would have chosen a different way; of course.
Selfishly, my plans would have never included an early miscarriage, 3 years of infertility, a late miscarriage of our twin and a remaining high risk pregnancy.

But I’m not living my life unto the glory of Amy; I’m living my life unto the glory of God. And in order for this to be accomplished in all of its fullness…my will has to die so His can flourish. In other words; “not my will, but Yours be done.”

I want what He wants for me. 

Friend, I don’t know where you find yourself today. Whether you’re scaling the high mountain of His tangible blessings, or you’re staggering through the darkened valley of trials and tribulations…I just want to remind you that our Good Shepherd is there, leading you in the midst of both places.

And for those who specifically find themselves in the valley, I want to say this; you’re not alone. You’ll be tempted to believe you’re alone, but you’re not. God is no less good, compassionate and sovereign in suffering. I know it may not be what you would have chosen, but will you still stand on His Word and choose to believe that His way is best?

I pray you do. 
I am standing with you 💛

•Psalm 27:13-14// I would have lost heart, unless I had believed that I would see the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living. Wait on the Lord; be of good courage, and He shall strengthen your heart; Wait, I say, on the Lord!

I love that Spurgeon said, “I have to”. Meaning, how could I not? 

How could I possibly become so entangled and self-consumed within the accolades, the good merits, the applause, the success, the materialism, the self-boasting…when the cross stands ready to remind me of the only truth that holds eternal value in my life?

To marvel that I’m even saved at all.

Not by my works, not by what I could ever accomplish in His Name…but by the sacrifice of Jesus Christ alone. 

From this perspective, finding any type of worth in anything else seems so frivolous and fleeting. 

Just thinking out loud 💛

In other words, living a life unto Christ is not always easy. Trials and hardships will happen. 

The wilderness where Jesus was tempted, the garden of gethsemane where Jesus prayed for God’s will to be done in suffering, and the foreseen betrayal of His disciple Judas.

If you knew someone was going turn their back on you, forsake you, abandon you…would you still choose humility? Would you still extend grace? Or would you instead choose bitterness, anger and unforgiveness? 

Knowing Judas would soon betray Him, knowing Peter would soon deny Him, knowing the disciples would hide in fear, Jesus still washed their feet.

Really think about that for a moment. Jesus came to earth not as a flashy, prestige king and conqueror, but as the suffering Servant spoken of in Isaiah 53. And as He revealed in Matthew 20:28, He came “not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.”

The meekness expressed by washing the feet of the disciples with a single towel and water basin foreshadowed His ultimate act of humility and love on the cross. John 13:1 explains it beautifully,

“Now before the Feast of the Passover, when Jesus knew that His hour had come that He should depart from this world to the Father, having loved His own who were in the world, He loved them to the end.”

He loved them to the end.

I’m convicted, inspired and thankful, all at the same time.

Jesus has set the perfect example, the question is, do we truly obey and follow?

Do we truly value humility and mirror this type of grace toward others, yes, even those who have hurt us? 

It’s a difficult thing. 

The servanthood and humility of Jesus is the type of leadership I strive to reflect here on earth every single day. I pray you do as well.

Some things just don't turn out the way that we plan or think they should, and as a Christian, especially during this time of year, we celebrate the fact that this isn't always a bad thing.

About 2000 years ago, the only people who would’ve considered this day as “good”, would be the ones who personally had a hand in the crucifixion of Jesus. This is what they wanted all along. 

Surely this man who challenged their love for traditions and claimed to forgive sins couldn’t be the Messiah! Not a man conceived out of “conspiracy”! Not a man born in a feeding trough! Not a man from Nazareth (“does anything good come from Nazareth?”). Not a man who works as a local carpenter! Not a man riding on a donkey! Not a man who passes on the earthly accolades and crowns for a kingdom unseen!

So, they crucified the “imposter” to their carnal familiarity. See, the religious at this time had no vision and no room for a suffering Messiah. They wanted a crowned king, dripping in riches and gold. 

What man purposes for evil, God always prevails for good. He gave His life as a ransom for many. This is why the day that Jesus died is a good, good day.

God was providing THE LAST Passover Lamb they would ever need. When they took the man Jesus, the Carpenter from Nazareth, the SON OF GOD, and they nailed Him to that tree, they never would have IMAGINED that He would take those nails and bloodstained wood, and build an entire Kingdom through His sacrifice! 

But you see, victory rarely ever looks like victory the moment that it is won. Revelation of the victory usually takes time.

Three days to be exact.

But until then, I leave you simply with this,

“It is finished."

We often think “big places, big things, big platforms” automatically means, successful ministry. But God uses a different measuring tool. He’s after the day-to-day obedience. He wants us to be a faithful light right where we are.

In our jobs around our coworkers, in our kitchen as we prepare dinner for the family, at the store when we stop to encourage a stranger. The way we witness to others, how we treat waiters and waitresses, customer service reps and even the homeless man or woman we pass on the side of the road every day. 

These are all opportunities to reach and love others. These are all daily opportunities to tell others about Jesus.

So, I want to encourage you. Wherever God has you right now; that’s your ministry field. Cultivate it well. Take care of it with great detail and attention.

Nothing is too small in His Kingdom. Not even the little mustard seed of faith can be passed off as insignificant because of it’s size.

Ministry is day-to-day and it will look different in every season. Don’t miss the opportunity just because it’s not packaged in the way you expected.

It’s a great responsibility to be a follower of Jesus.

We’ve been given the gospel to share and a world to reach; did we think this call would come without trial and tribulation? Surely we are not ignorant of what Jesus said to His disciples in John 15:18-21 (see scripture below). 

Become strong in studying God’s Word. 
Learn it, memorize it, apply it. 
Cultivate a diligent prayer life.
Use what God gave you to bring Him glory.

Through the ministry of the Holy Spirit, these are what will strengthen you and sustain you in the days ahead.

Opinions won’t matter, threats won’t matter, fear mongering won’t matter…because you didn’t build your life upon the shifting sands of this fallen world. You built upon the rock; Christ Jesus. When everyone else shape shifts and bows to modern day idols, you’ll stand tall unafraid of that burning furnace. You know the 4th Man who accompanies in the fire; what does it matter what the others can do to you?

Stand strong, in Christ alone. 

•John 15:18-21// “If the world hates you, know that it has hated me before it hated you. Remember the word that I said to you: ‘A servant is not greater than his master.’ If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you. If they kept my word, they will also keep yours. •Hebrews 13:6- So we can confidently say, “The Lord is my helper; I will not fear; what can man do to me?”

•Ephesians 6:19-20// And also for me, that words may be given to me in opening my mouth boldly to proclaim the mystery of the gospel, for which I am an ambassador in chains, that I may declare it boldly, as I ought to speak.

The fear of man is a snare and hinderance.

I had to decide a long time ago that letting myself get worked up over opposition, backlash and mere opposing personal opinions was no longer an option in my life. 

If I wanted to truly serve God on His terms and by His Word, I needed to be accepting of the fact that it would provoke a lot of trials and hostility. To be honest, when I first became a Christian, that used to really scare me. I mean, at the very moment of confrontation my heart used to race and anxiety came in like a flood.

Once again; the fear of man is a snare and hinderance. 

When I recognized this for what it truly was, it was quite easy to let go of.

Fear of man is a form of idolatry, and the thought of revolving my entire life around trying to please everyone else instead of God, made me angry because Jesus didn’t die for me to live stuck in bondage to a lie. 

My encouragement today is simple. If you can relate to anything I’ve said, I’m glad you know you’re not alone. Being a follower of Jesus isn’t easy. I hope someone was honest with you and told you that at some point.

You’ll be attacked, cancelled, and wildly misunderstood. You’ll be too much for some and not enough for others. Some won’t like your choice of words and delivery. Some will think you’re too bold and not enough love, others will say you’re too much love and not enough boldness. Some will just flat out not like YOU. 

Will you let it silence your voice?
I pray the answer is no. 

Continue to stand on God’s Word.
Continue to adhere to Truth. 
Continue to be bold, in love, at all times.
Continue to address the hard things when needed.

Praying for you today and always💛

How easy it is to assume we’ve worn out God’s attention with our prayers. How easy it is to cave into our emotions and feel as if we are becoming an inconvenience to God.

•Inconvenience: to cause difficulty, annoyance, to bother or aggravate.

See, by nature, we often gauge our relationship with God to earthly experience. We adapt to taking broken personality traits of broken people we’ve known in our lives and we attach those fractured pieces to our Heavenly Father.

Maybe someone made you to feel that you were hard to love, so you think God has decided the same of you. Maybe you never really experienced genuine affection, so you keep God at a distance because vulnerability makes you feel uncomfortable. Maybe you’ve felt the sting of rejection throughout your life, so you approach God on the defense just in case He rejects you too. Or maybe, just maybe, you were taught some wrong things about God that portrayed Him to be a distant Tyrant ruling on His throne, so you think He’s completely checked out and unconcerned with your life. 

Wherever you find yourself today, I just want you to know that you are not an inconvenience to God. 

Remember the parable of the persistent widow that Jesus gave in Luke 18:1-8? It says that He shared this parable so, “that men always ought to pray and not lose heart”.

It was her persistence that set her apart and her request was granted. Or how about Matthew 7:7-12, where Jesus tells us to keep asking, seeking and knocking and reminds us, “If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask Him!”

Friend, God is not on His throne caught off guard by you. He’s not annoyed that you’ve come to Him, yet again, with the same prayer. He’s not like man. His ways and thoughts are higher. His grace; unparalleled.

Once again, you are not an inconvenience to God, and I hope that shifts the way you view Him and approach Him from this day forward.

I invite you today to join me in evaluating where we’ve taken our stand.

If you call yourself a follower of Jesus, are you making sure to work out your own salvation with fear and trembling (Philippians 2:12)?

Are you aligning yourself with worldly belief systems and agendas that are causing you to stir the pot of demonic division and hatred toward others?

Are you advocating for causes that are pitted against the Kingdom of God and His incorruptible Word?

Would Jesus stand along side of you and nod His head in approval of what you say and how you treat others?

These are questions we *all* need to ask ourselves to challenge, correct and edify where needed.

Because in all truth, we are followers of Jesus Christ FIRST and ABOVE ALL. Everything else comes thereafter and must align with His cause. If it doesn’t, we don’t walk, we RUN from it. We don’t coddle and pacify what scripture tells us to stand against. May we bolden our witness for His name’s sake alone.

Disappointments are familiar to all of us. 

We cultivate an expectation for a desired outcome, we pray, we believe, we hold onto our faith, we cling to the Word…and it doesn’t work out. The outcome is the opposite, the bad news is worse than we feared, the rug feels like it has been pulled out from under us…and if we are going to be honest…all we are left with is our questions and tears. 

You can trust the will of God and yet still grieve. 

Perhaps that sounds a little overdramatic to someone reading this, but for those who have endured countless large and small disappointments in life, this will sound like familiar territory.

And that’s who I am speaking to today.
I felt the need to exhort, remind and encourage those who are facing disappointment.

Maybe it’s a loss of some sort, a closed door to a desired opportunity, a failing marriage, waiting to find a spouse, a declining diagnosis, the heartache of wayward children or relatives, lack of support from family or friends, countless months or years of infertility or miscarriage, financial issues, and the list could continue on for miles.

My encouragement is simple today, and something deep down inside, you already know.

Cling to the Lord.
Hold fast to the faithfulness of His Word.
Pray and pour your heart out before Him.

As David once said…

•Psalm 42:11- Why are you cast down, O my soul, and why are you in turmoil within me? Hope in God; for I shall again praise him, my salvation and my God.

Will it change the circumstance? Perhaps, but if it doesn’t, something in you will change. For the good, may I add.

See, if you choose to hold on to disappointed faith, it can soon lead to a hardened heart toward God. You’ll be swallowed up in unbelief, numb to encouragement, and cynical in your approach toward faith. God doesn’t want you in that territory, and neither do I.

Here are some scriptures I urge you to look up, read, write down, and even memorize if you feel led. These will help you in the days ahead when disappointment and discouragement show up in your life.

•Romans 8:28

If you’ve decided to go all in for Jesus, just know that you’ve made the greatest decision you could ever make on earth.

But this decision will come with backlash if you live obedient to God and His Word. Eventually you will be faced with circumstances where you will have to make a decision to stand for biblical Truth. This should come at no surprise, just take a look at the world today.

Will you stand in boldness?
Will you bend to social pressure?

The more you study the scriptures and the more you pray, the more confidence you will gain to live unto God despite what the world will think. You’ll be unmoved by the praise of men and you will live with holy unction.

Continue on, friend, the cost is well worth the reward! Keep your eyes on Jesus and your perspective on heaven.

I was reading 1John 5:4 and something very simple yet valuable reached out to me. It says,

“For everyone who has been born of God overcomes the world. And this is the victory that has overcome the world—our faith.”

It’s amazing to me because so many people, even Christians, place their faith in things, people and places over investing their whole faith in God and His Word. Then we wonder why we live defeated.

So why would you place your faith in anything other than what promises you the victory?

I don’t know either.

Friends, we have all we need in the Lord.

“Lord, to whom would we go? You have the words that give eternal life.”

This photo means so much to me. It resembles the ultrasound photo that I have of both Uriah and Zane when they were together at about 14 weeks in utero. This is about the same time that Zane is said to have passed away.

When we found out we were having fraternal twin boys, I had eagerly planned how life would soon look taking care of these precious boys together.

I envisioned the newborn photos of them cuddling together, nursing both of them together, sharing milestones and birthdays together, growing up and growing old together. 

Built in best friends. 

One day I will share with Uriah that he has a twin and a part of him resides in heaven. I’ll share the ultrasound photos and I’ll explain to him that his middle name is a tribute to his sweet brother. I’ll explain how God kept both him and I safe during the pregnancy, and how good and sovereign God is in all of His ways, even when we don’t understand His plan.

So, for everyone who has walked this journey with me, I just wanted to share this sweet photo of my boys; one here on earth and one living his fullest life in heaven.

Thank You, Lord for answering my prayer and blessing my family with twins. Earth is fleeting and temporary. Eternity is forever.

What a glorious reunion it will be.

In Matthew 11, John the Baptist had been wrongfully imprisoned and in his current state of possible concern, he set a few of his followers out to ask Jesus a question; “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”

Jesus answered and told the disciples to tell John all that they had seen and heard. Then in verse 6, He sent them away with an important declaration;

“And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”

Offense can attractively present itself as a reasonable response when hurt is present. Jesus understood this and He was aware of the schemes of the devil.

Consider this: John the Baptist is sitting in prison and he is going to be executed. Perhaps he didn’t think his 6 month ministry as a forerunner for the Messiah was going to end like this. How easy it would be to fall into confusion and doubt everything he stood for...including Jesus.

John and his disciples had to be open to God’s unfolding plan despite it not matching their expectations. The good news is; the kindness of Jesus reached out with understanding and compassion. He immediately combated the possibility for offense.

“Blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”

Hurt happens. Things won’t go as planned. People will do things and it will cause pain. I’m not excusing bad behavior, but I am inviting you to be set free.

Living offended is a choice. Hear me please; LIVING OFFENDED IS A CHOICE. It’s false justice. It’s also bait given by the enemy. Because if the enemy can grab ahold of your hurt, he will transition it to offense. And if that offense sits long enough, it will soon sour into bitterness.

Friend, please do not live in a constant state of offense. Do not live offended by man nor by God.

Attend to the wounds in your life, pray and release this to the Lord. Ask Him for the help you need to forgive and let go.

Remember: Forgiveness isn’t saying the offense or offender is right; it’s saying that what Jesus did on the cross is right.

I pray that we, as followers of Jesus, always choose to love without hypocrisy.

I pray that we always treat relational repentance and reconciliation with just as much importance as we do with other facets of ministry.

It all matters to God; therefore it should matter to us.

Surrender.

When we found out our twin boy, Zane had passed away at 14 weeks, I remember telling my mother, “I don’t know how I’m going to get to the other side of this.” 

She replied, “By going through. I know you want to rush this process of grieving and healing, but you can’t. Let God do His work.”

Once again…surrender. 

I went through 5 difficult months of carrying twin brothers…one alive in heaven and one alive here on earth.

Sometimes God’s will requires a certain breaking accompanied by many tears in order to get through to the other side of His purpose.

Could He accomplish His plans without the pain? Certainly. But then, I believe, we would miss the opportunity to know Him on an intimate level that seems to sweetly arrive through a certain measure of suffering. 

I would have chosen a different way; of course.
Selfishly, my plans would have never included an early miscarriage, 3 years of infertility, a late miscarriage of our twin and a remaining high risk pregnancy.

But I’m not living my life unto the glory of Amy; I’m living my life unto the glory of God. And in order for this to be accomplished in all of its fullness…my will has to die so His can flourish. In other words; “not my will, but Yours be done.”

I want what He wants for me. 

Friend, I don’t know where you find yourself today. Whether you’re scaling the high mountain of His tangible blessings, or you’re staggering through the darkened valley of trials and tribulations…I just want to remind you that our Good Shepherd is there, leading you in the midst of both places.

And for those who specifically find themselves in the valley, I want to say this; you’re not alone. You’ll be tempted to believe you’re alone, but you’re not. God is no less good, compassionate and sovereign in suffering. I know it may not be what you would have chosen, but will you still stand on His Word and choose to believe that His way is best?

I pray you do. 
I am standing with you 💛

There is a difference between flattery and encouragement; did you know that? 

First, I want to give you the definition of flattery: “excessive and insincere praise, given especially to further one's own interests.”

Now, I want to give you the definition of encouragement: “the action of giving someone support, confidence, or hope.”

Can you spot the difference between the two?

It’s about the heart posture. Flattery is inSINcere and self-seeking. Encouragement is supportive and honoring.

This may come as a surprise, but there are many verses in the Bible that clearly warn about flattery. Here are a few...

•Psalm 5:9- There is nothing reliable in what they say; Their inward part is destruction itself. Their throat is an open grave; They flatter with their tongue.

•Jeremiah 9:8- Their tongue is a deadly arrow; It speaks deceit; With his mouth one speaks peace to his neighbor, But inwardly he sets an ambush for him.

•Proverbs 26:28- A lying tongue hates those it crushes, And a flattering mouth works ruin.

How easily this falls under the, “Christian radar”. How common it is among us. Yet how crucial it is to learn the severity.

Have you ever wanted your way in something and knew how to covertly work the other person to get it? That’s flattery. Have you ever given excessive praise to someone knowing you soon needed a favor or wanted something in return? That’s flattery. Have you ever told someone something false because it’s what they wanted to hear just to make them happy? That’s flattery.

Flattery is the “sweet talk” of the devil. It devises evil, it is often filled with jealousy and deceit, and it tries to overcompensate and conceal it’s wickedness by giving excessive praise and adoration. Flattery has hidden motives. It’s sweet sounding and it “butters up” the ears of those who are it’s target. All for 3 purposes: manipulation, control, and deceit. This is the devil’s work and we are to take no part in it.

Friends, may our yes be yes and our no be no. May we encourage one another with truth and humility. May we live and speak honestly. May we use the Word of God as our tool to speak love and honor. May our hearts be pure and right before Him, and others.

Living for the approval of others is an idol that must be destroyed.

It’s time to get bold in your obedience to God and making the right decisions for your family, regardless of whether or not others agree with you.

If you don’t decide what’s right for you and your family, especially according to scripture, make no mistake about it, someone or something else will decide for you. 

This world is filled with differing opinions. They’ll tell you how to live, how to speak, how to feel, how to think, how to make decisions, how to raise your children, how to work, how to vote, how to serve, how to eat, how to spend your money, and even who or what to worship.

As followers of Jesus, serving and honoring others must never come at the price of ignoring our own conscience, avoiding scripture, and dishonoring God. What a price to pay to live in fear of offending others all for the sake of obtaining false peace.

When the world presses us, we must press back harder. Not in violence and hate, but in authority and love. Not in aggression and anger, but in boldness and truth. 

As for me and my house, we shall serve the Lord. Put me on the record for that and that alone.

•Joshua 24:15- And if it is evil in your eyes to serve the Lord, choose this day whom you will serve, whether the gods your fathers served in the region beyond the River, or the gods of the Amorites in whose land you dwell. But as for me and my house, we will serve the Lord.

I’m convicted because many times I have believed that an immediate change in my circumstances would be the defining moment of an answered prayer.

Yet, how easily I forget that Christ in me, the hope of glory, is a matchless sufficiency that far exceeds any desired change or outcome.

Of course sometimes it would just be easier to change the circumstance, but if I desire to grow in Christ, I must allow God to use difficult circumstances to first change me.

There is grace to travel through the valleys.
There is faith to carry us to the other side.
There is hope, always hope, because we have a Good Shepherd caring for us.

Present day, this ideology is being poured out rapidly in our culture and anyone who dares to stand against it is met with swift banishment.

Speak out with truth anyway.

Stay vigilant. Stay prayed up. Know the truth of God’s Word so you can discern the deception of the devil and warn others when they begin to fall away.

When Jesus spoke, not everyone received His words with eager gladness.

Light shining into the darkness is a recipe for exposure. But exposure is needed so the choice of freedom can be obtained.

The question is, are you willing to face rejection in order to reach the lost?

Are you willing to be misunderstood, mocked, laughed at and even cussed out? It all comes with the territory of a believer…

John 15:18-19 says, 
“If the world hates you, know that it has hated me before it hated you. If you were of the world, the world would love you as its own; but because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.”

If you’ve picked up your cross and now follow Jesus, the answer will be an immediate, “yes”. 

Truth can be offensive, but far be it from us to hold back the truth out of some flesh-induced fear of rejection.

The good news of the Gospel is our mandate! The message of the cross calls for repentance. Once lost, now found! Jesus is the only way! This is our declaration to a lost world and it often provokes resistance. Declare it all the more.

If building up a “name” and chasing after fame becomes our focal point for ministry; then our bottom line is off. Way off. If we are seeking friendship with the world and our love has become merely transactional; our motives are corrupt.

Nothing is more important than sharing the Gospel and declaring the full truth of God’s Word. Seeing people set free is the goal. And quite honestly, I’d rather be picked apart for proclaiming truth than becoming popular for projecting lies.
