I’ve been reading out of Ephesians 5 today, and noticed how the title says, “Walk in Love”. Yet, what I find interesting is verses 3-21 expound on the fact that we as believers are called to come up higher, live in holiness, and expose the unfruitful works of darkness.

Plainly put: walking as children of the light means not engaging in the sins of the unbelieving culture. We love people; but we don’t sin with them. 

I point that out because present day, standing up for biblical truth will now label you as harsh and hateful. Somehow, we have come to the conclusion that love equals passivity with no room for correction. 

In Ephesians 5, Paul reiterates the type of conduct that is expected of a believer. Paul says that what we tolerate and basically sugar coat matters just as much. He calls it out by name, go read the entire chapter.

But here is my favorite part. In verse 11, he not only tells us to avoid fellowship (friendly association) with the unfruitful works of darkness, but he takes it a step further and tells us to instead, EXPOSE the unfruitful works of darkness. It’s a stance of defense and offense.

So why was it so important for Paul to instruct us in this way? Because we have been called out of darkness and into the marvelous light of Christ. When we fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness/sin, when we have friendly association with darkness/sin, when we dilute down the severity and passively justify our apathy toward darkness/sin; we are in error and Paul says we are deceived.

Friends, may deception have no place. Ephesians 5:1-2 says to be imitators of God as beloved children and to walk in love. Walking in love provides grace; but walking in love also means being rooted in truth. And as we read on to verse 11, truth is not afraid to denounce and expose the unfruitful works of darkness.

Therefore neither should we.

•Ephesians 5:8-11//For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light (for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth), finding out what is acceptable to the Lord. And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather expose them.

It’s always wise to take inventory of your words, your decisions, your actions and your motives.

How do you treat people?
Do you consider others to be beneath you?
How do you speak of others when they are not present?
Do you push boundaries or do you honor them?
Do you seek to control or can you love unconditionally?
Do you surround yourself with people who feed your needs or do you equally give out as much as you require?
Are you honest or do you manipulate?

This. All. Matters.

It’s something God has been placing on my heart a lot lately. We are responsible for our words and our actions as those who openly profess Christ. We are a living example and testament to the Gospel. We must use these areas to live out the Truth we declare and to also love others well. These are not interchangeable. 

Consider the severity of this, because in all honesty; God takes our words very seriously. He takes loving people very seriously. He takes using people very seriously.

We know what our Bible says.

May our lips and our lives never preach two conflicting messages.

I’m not saying it’s an easy road. It’s not.

I would love to bring God the glory through other avenues that represent hilltops rather than valleys, but there’s no resurrection without the cross, and there’s no cross without Gethsemane. 

My prayer this year has been for God to help me die to self.

I would say that prayer is definitely being answered.

But it was needed. I’m in this for the long haul and I know the good that can come from refinement.

Some old dreams need to die.
Some desires need to be tabled.
Some things need to be released.

I feel an urgency to clean house so I can fully make room for God’s will. How else can He truly have His way in my life if I do not FULLY surrender?

The more I read His Word, the more I am reminded of His character, His intentions and His goodness. Because of this, how could I not trust?

Even when my flesh tries to tell me that impossibilities are more predominant, I have to believe His provision is promising.

If this resonates, I’m so glad.

Here are some scriptures I’m reading today, and I pray you enjoy them as well.

•Isaiah 26:4- Trust in the Lord forever, for the Lord God is an everlasting rock.

•Proverbs 30:5- Every word of God proves true; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.

•Psalm 27:14- Wait for the Lord; be strong, and let your heart take courage; wait for the Lord!

•Psalm 31:19- Oh, how abundant is your goodness, which you have stored up for those who fear you and worked for those who take refuge in you, in the sight of the children of mankind!

•Proverbs 3:5-6// Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and do not lean on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make straight your paths.

I know I’ve said this before, but at the risk of sounding like a broken record, I’m genuinely asking: has the enemy gained a foothold in this area?

Speaking from experience, it’s good to take inventory of your life and evaluate where you are investing your time.

Ok, more questions…

Are you reading your Bible? Have you given some time to spend with God? Do you pray and intercede? Are you growing in Christ and in the knowledge of the Holy One? (2Peter 3:18)

This isn’t legalism; this is about spiritual maturity and growing in the Lord during an era where evil is now called good, and good is now called evil. This is the greatest investment you can make on earth.

No condemnation. No need to get offended. If you find yourself in need of slightly shifting your time and priorities, well then, make the change right now.

Whether you work on location or at home, currently unemployed, constantly taking care of your children, whether you’re retired or in a season of transition...I’m telling you...your schedule CAN be reordered to prioritize the Lord. 

And please don’t get caught up in the amount of “time spent”. This is where many people get discouraged and think that reading for 10-15 minutes on their busiest day isn’t enough, so they scrap their whole plan to read the Bible entirely. 

Sometimes it’s as easy as setting aside your phone, tablet or laptop and simply picking up your Bible. Start there. 

Enjoy this time with Him.

I’ve said this before, but it’s worth saying again given all we see in the world today.

Must we stay informed with world events? Without question. But it requires work. We are not to be led blindly. Instead, we are to use wisdom and discernment when obtaining knowledge. 

I’m going to speak plainly here for a moment. The mainstream media news outlets are sadly not reliable to provide accurate information that we need to know. Key word: NEED.

I’m not merely talking about carnal facts; I’m talking about biblical Truth as well. At this point in time, most everything you see and hear on a large scale is deeply infiltrated in corrupt propaganda. 

Now, before you label me as a whack-a-doo conspiracy theorist for using the risky word, “propaganda”, please be informed of its definition. 

Propaganda: information, especially of a biased or misleading nature, used to promote or publicize a particular political cause or point of view.

This is why I said we need discernment to distinguish right from almost right.

Simply trusting a source without investigating who they truly are, what they stand for, and what else they have said, could very well lead to deep deception. Sure, there are some with a major platform who have chosen to still walk on the narrow path and deliver unaltered truth, but that number is small. Very small.

So my charge for you today is simple and has not changed: Study, read and pray. That’s your deterrent to deception. Study your Bible, read on a daily basis and pray without ceasing.

Do I sound like a broken record yet?🤗

Friends, spiritual warfare is an ancient battle.
There is nothing new under the sun.
Your Bible hasn’t changed.

Always.

When I think of Joseph in the Old Testament, I think of his profound humility.

If Joseph’s jealous brothers had not sold him to traders, to then be sold to Potiphar, to then be wrongfully accused and put into prison, to then go from the prison to the palace....I wonder how Joseph would’ve gotten to be second in command to pharaoh? 

God worked it all for good, didn’t He?

God used the mistreatment of others to accompany His plans for the future leadership He had installed into Joseph. He also used the mistreatment of others to refine the character of Joseph.

It all had a purpose. 

The end result? Joseph became a trustworthy leader, second in command to Pharaoh. But to me, the most amazing part of his story is the humility and grace that Joseph showed towards his brothers who rejected him and meant evil toward him.

•Genesis 50:20- As for you, you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good in order to bring about this present result, to save many lives.

God’s plan for Joseph far exceeded Joseph. This was just a small piece in a much larger puzzle, so to speak, that was used to prepare an entire nation for plenty and for famine.

You know; I’m not sure how long it took Joseph to fully forgive his brothers for what they had done to him. He sure did have a lot of time to process it all while wrongfully sitting in prison.

But by looking at the way the scriptures continuously mention that God was with Joseph, something tells me he forgave and showed grace because he walked in that type of closeness with God.

When you’ve been shown kindness and grace from God, and when you walk in His favor, it cultivates compassion in you toward others. Yes, even those who have dealt unfairly with you.

God meant it all for good in Joseph’s life.

Are you facing opposition?

God can use it all for good in yours. 

And there’s no better story than when He receives the glory.

•Psalm 105:19- Until the time that his word came to pass, The word of the Lord tested him.

•1Peter 5:10- And the God of all grace, who called you to his eternal glory in Christ, after you have suffered a little while, will himself restore you and make you strong, firm and steadfast.

And we still need that grace. Every. Single. Day.

You know, we won’t be so quick to magnify the flaws and issues in others when we stop to consider all of the grace and forgiveness we’ve been so graciously given by God.

Remember all that Christ saved you from? Remember the goodness of God and how it led you to repentance? Remember when the story of the woman caught in adultery spoke to your heart so deeply? Remember when Jesus looked at her and said, “...then neither do I condemn you. Go and sin no more”?

Or how about the woman at the well? Remember her story? Remember when Jesus knew her sin and shame and still found her worthy to declare His Name?

How quickly we forget sometimes.

Friends, do not let your hearts grow cold. Compassion travels great distances where others are not willing to go.

May the sin of self-righteousness have no place among us as followers of Jesus Christ. Amen? Amen.

I know this isn’t your typical holiday post. So first allow me to start off by saying, Happy Thanksgiving to everyone! I’m thankful today (and every day), for Jesus Christ and all of the blessings in my life.

But I really wanted to hop on here quickly to share something a little different. Like every holiday, while in prayer this morning, I felt led to intercede for those who are grieving or having an exceptionally difficult time today. 

To the ones who:
•Lost a loved one recently or around this time of year in the past...
•Are missing parents, grandparents, children, relatives and friends who have passed away...
•Are alone, shut up in their homes for reasons beyond their control…
•Are dealing with a tragedy or difficult life event…
•Are missing a family member(s) at the table due to them being in the service...
•Battle infertility or loss and long for children (or more children), of their own to celebrate with...
•Have had a family change due to divorce and things look very different this year...
•Are waiting on the Lord for a spouse...
•Are anxious about paying bills and buying gifts this year due to losing a job or living pay check to pay check...
•Have traumatic memories attached to holidays...
•Battle, (or know someone battling) illness, disease, addiction, eating disorders, who have an especially hard time during a holiday that is revolved around constant eating and cheers to, “good health”...
•Don’t feel loved or have strained relationships with loved ones...

I want you to know that I see you, I am here for you and I am so sorry.

Today, extend a lot of grace to yourself. You can be thankful and yet still grieve. God’s peace is sufficient for both.

Pray and take some time away from the “rush”, and just be still for a few moments. God cares deeply for you and if you ask Him, He will give you abundant peace for your heart and mind through Christ Jesus.

I love you and I’m praying for you today.

From Genesis to Revelation, the goodness of God has been exalted and we have a sort of blueprint, if you will, that provides the knowledge of what was, what is, and what is to come.

The world may be falling apart, but His plans are not.

It’s hard to think of reproach, hatred and backlash as a blessing, but it’s true.

If you are a follower of Jesus, boldly sharing the gospel and standing on the truth of God’s Word in this dark generation, you will face persecution of some kind. It may or may not be persecution that leads to bodily harm or death, but nonetheless, we will endure the persecution as it is by definition: hostility and ill treatment. 

Sadly, many strive to live a life of avoidance. Love somehow is preached as passivity and standing for truth becomes too controversial for their standard. They become afraid of disagreements and upsetting the masses, which ultimately lures them into a life of people-pleasing and bowing to a culture that will bully every word they try to speak. A change of perspective is needed.

Instead of avoiding persecution and backlash, we need to accept it and expect it as a response that comes with the territory of a believer. Why do we live afraid of something that we are told is a blessing? Probably because we know it’s not easy. But to suffer for the glory of God is an honor, and the moment we begin to look at it that way, we will embrace it with the strength of the Lord. No matter what comes our way. 

•Matthew 5:10- “Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.”

•1Peter 4:12-16//  Beloved, do not think it strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened to you; but rejoice to the extent that you partake of Christ’s sufferings, that when His glory is revealed, you may also be glad with exceeding joy. If you are reproached for the name of Christ, blessed are you, for the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you. On their part He is blasphemed, but on your part He is glorified. But let none of you suffer as a murderer, a thief, an evildoer, or as a busybody in other people’s matters. Yet if anyone suffers as a Christian, let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God in this matter.

I take great comfort in reading about the life of Joseph in the Old Testament. 

Was it difficult for him to hold onto the promise God gave him in a dream when he was held captive in the pit?

His present circumstances didn’t match the future blessing. 

But as we learn, the pit was purposeful, not pointless. 

Through all of the trials, confusion and pain that Joseph went through, we are told one very important piece of information in Genesis 39:2,

“The Lord was with Jospeh…”

Oh, be still, my heart. The God of all comfort and mercy never leaves. 

Difficult trials, painful hardships, seeming setbacks and even great loss are not indications that God has left us. 

Instead, He walks with us.

He stays. 

Perhaps this is the reason why we are still able to see in the dark valleys. Because His Word…especially in the darkness…is truly the only light unto our path that gives us the ability to continue walking forward.

So today, I just wanted to remind you that God has not abandoned you. 

I know how dark that pit can be. 
I know how hopeless it can seem.
I know how “alone” you may feel. 

But He is with you. 

Cling to the presence and purposefulness of God. When you cannot perceive Him; cling all the more.

He is there, and you are not alone.

I think we tend to overlook the simple things.

For many, if ministry is not packaged on some type of grandiose scale, we think it doesn’t hold as much significance. And that’s simply not true.

As I’ve been reading through the gospels lately, there’s one thing I notice of Jesus that has been really speaking to me a lot: He took time for people.

It was almost a complete shock to many. The religious leaders during that time sectioned themselves off from society and often didn’t associate with the “simpletons”.

Yet, Jesus arrives on the scene and operates a different way. He doesn’t just preach a message; He actually lives it. He doesn’t require prestige glory and honor, instead He arrives to seek, serve and save the lost. 

Who was this Man who took time for the sick, lame, depressed, and demon possessed?

What business did He have, as a Jew, to travel through Samaria to speak with the outcasted woman at the well?

What was He thinking to bend down to the woman caught in adultery to look her in the eye when everyone else looked down on her?

What about all of the people He healed? He touched those who were untouchable to society. 

He listened to the woman’s story with the issue of blood as she shared her suffering and pain. 

He wept with Mary and Martha out of compassion for their grieving. He reached out, He listened, He comforted, He provided truth. 

I’m convicted by this. I want to be more like Jesus. I really want to do better in this area. I want to listen well, love others well, and yet not sacrifice the truth of the gospel...all at the same time.

Do you feel the same? Would you join me today in praying for the Holy Spirit to help us be more attentive to others while sharing the truth of His Word? It’s truly so important.

Some people despise birthdays as they grow older. Especially in the type of society we are living in today, hiding your age is the norm, growing old is considered a burden, and marketing is geared toward enhancing youth rather than embracing the process of aging.

I also have immense gratitude for the community I’ve found here on social media with like-minded believers. I’ve made some life-long friends due to this space, and I’m thankful for everyone here who has always been so supportive, kind, and generous to my family and I. It genuinely means more to me than you’ll ever know.

Love y’all 💛

I’m not sure how your 2023 personally played out. I don’t know what you endured these last 12 months.

I’m not aware of what you had to face and all of the highs and lows that transitioned your life to where it is today.

But I DO know this; it’s about to be a new year and newness has the potential of bringing hope.

Yes, I have hope. 

“New” can be exciting; but new often = change. 

We are a people who often do not like change. Why? Because change disrupts the norm. 

Change often shifts schedules and switches the familiar course.

Maybe you’re like me and ready for a brand new change with new opportunities in 2024. Maybe you were already forced to face some type of change that has now left you weary and fearful. Wherever you find yourself today; I do want to encourage you.

Where there is change, God still remains the same.

God works in the changes of life. He really does. He restores, He vindicates, He aligns, He rebuilds, He comforts, He provides.

I can’t promise you everything will change instantly once the clock strikes midnight tonight. 

And you know what? It more than likely won’t. 

But the truth is; things very rarely ever change in a moment. Think timing. There’s a process attached to everything, and the process is the avenue that brings you to where God has purposed you to be.

My friend, release 2023 to God with an expectant heart of worship for what’s to come. Dedicate 2024 into His hands and prayerfully place all of your desires and needs for this New Year underneath His Lordship.

He will never fail you, and neither will His Word.

•Lamentations 3:22-23// The steadfast love of the Lord never ceases; his mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great is your faithfulness.

Perhaps your life won’t look like everyone else’s this year.

You know the routine; new year, new goals, new projects, new opportunities, new plans etc. But I’m inviting you to take a step back for a moment and heed the leading of the Lord.

WHAT IF (and I’m not saying this is for everyone), but WHAT IF God isn’t calling you to automatically sprint into this new year as a busy little bee🐝? What if He is calling you to start 2024 in complete and total REST?

Would you be alright with that? While everyone around you is hitting the gym with their new membership, starting extensive bible plans, diving into new projects, cultivating new business strategies, would you be comfortable with the fact that God is calling you to lean into His leading and simply rest? 

If the thought of that makes you anxious, we may be onto something here, because rest should never make you anxious. 

Here’s my encouragement: you don’t need to be busy to be fruitful.

You don’t need to keep up with everyone else to feel accomplished.

You don’t need to have countless new goals, and “hit the ground running” plans to welcome the new year with wisdom.

If you feel led, take some time to pray and seek the Lord this month. Yes, I said this month. The whole entire month. Let yourself off the hook of trying to fill up your calendar and appear as the woman who “does it all.” 

Life is not a competition.
Success is not a competition.
Marriage is not a competition.
Motherhood is not a competition.
Ministry is not a competition.
Friendship is not a competition.

Rest from all the carnal striving.

Seek the Lord, and if even for a moment, make it a point to rest this year. Because within that rest, you will find more fulfillment in His presence than you ever could in all of your “doing”. Trust me on that one.

•Matthew 11:28-30//Come to me, all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn from me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.

•Psalm 116:7- Return, O my soul, to your rest; for the Lord has dealt bountifully with you.

My message is simple today: avoid those who constantly sow dissension and quietly create discord among others. Nothing good ever comes from careless words that are crafted to tear people down. 

Proverbs 20:19 says it best, “Whoever goes about slandering reveals secrets; therefore do not associate with a simple babbler.”

You know the types I’m referring to. They like to stir the pot, create drama, amplify imperfections, pit people against one another, discuss the personal business of others, and gossip under the guise of a “prayer request”.

They seemingly receive an adrenaline rush talking negatively about people.

Sadly, as Christians, this is way too common in many friend circles, community groups, and church culture. 

In short, giving a listening ear to gossip and backbiting is friendly association with wickedness. If you’re not careful, you will end up forming an unjust opinion of someone merely by the malicious words of another.

Plainly put, it’s aiding and abetting in the destruction of someone’s character, and God takes that very seriously. 

The Bible warns of this because what is sown, will soon produce harvest.

Words produce life or death. Who you associate with will affect your life negatively or positively because as it says in 1Corinthians 15:33, bad company corrupts good morals.

Friends, take inventory of what you are saying and what you are listening to.

Confiding in a trusted friend about your life issue is ok; but doing it with the intent to wrongfully and maliciously talk about someone else is sin. It all comes down to our “why”. This is where a lot of us misstep and miss it entirely. 

Here are some scriptures to keep as a reminder in case you are tempted in this area in the future.

•Proverbs 17:9- Whoever covers an offense seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates close friends.

•Proverbs 26:28- A lying tongue hates its victims, and a flattering mouth works ruin.

•1Timothy 5:13- Besides that, they learn to be idlers, going about from house to house, and not only idlers, but also gossips and busybodies, saying what they should not.

•Proverbs 16:28 - A dishonest man spreads strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.

Despite popular belief, “pray for your enemies”, is not a passive aggressive phrase to appear self-righteous.

It’s a declaration from Jesus, and if anyone had the right to speak on this matter, it would be Him.

During the ministry of Jesus, He was often wildly misunderstood.

As a matter of fact, a group of religious men known as the Pharisees and Sadducees would often follow His travel plans to attend His gatherings all for one purpose: to try and catch Him in some sort of error or hypocrisy (Matthew 22:15, Mark 12:13). They once even accused Him of working with the ruler of demons, Beelzebub, to cast out demons (Matthew 12:24). 

Jesus, however perceived their intentions. Yet despite their hatred for Him, Jesus can never be found in a stature of forbidding them to attend where He ministered.

Time after time they were given opportunities to look past their legalism and instead perceive the new covenant of relationship. But they completely missed it.

Their theology had no room for a suffering messiah from Nazareth.

They were looking for a prestige King that fit inside of their box of worldly interpretations.

God often does things outside of our understanding, and if we merely judge based upon what we see, we too can be found in error of missing what God is doing in our midst.

So I want to encourage you today. As you continue serving the Lord, there will be people who will choose to be fully committed to misunderstanding you.

You’ll live under their microscope. You’ll be judged and dissected. You’ll be accused of many things and you’ll be the subject of countless smear campaigns...but so was Jesus.

And unlike Jesus who was fully God and fully man, absent of all error and folly, you WILL make mistakes along the way. 

You will stumble at times, you will need correction and you will often learn through trial and error, but growing pains do not discredit you when you are constantly being changed into the likeness of Christ.

Only God eternally defines you. Always remember that.

•Matthew 5:44- But I say to you, love your enemies, bless those who curse you, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who spitefully use you and persecute you.

If standing in solidarity with something or someone requires you to somehow compromise your biblical convictions, then make no mistake about it, God did not call you to advocate in that lane.

Please do not be deceived by what the world says you need to come into alignment with.

We can talk all day, we can debate, we can offer our personal opinion, but we must return to our solid foundation to ensure it is biblical truth. 

Because honestly? It’s very easy to get swallowed up in what WE think is right. But this isn’t about what WE think is right; this is about what GOD SAYS is right. How fortunate we are to have HIS TRUTH. The only Truth!

•Romans 12:2- Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect.

•Galatians 1:10- For am I now seeking the approval of man, or of God? Or am I trying to please man? If I were still trying to please man, I would not be a servant of Christ.

•1Corinthians 10:13- No temptation has overtaken you that is not common to man. God is faithful, and he will not let you be tempted beyond your ability, but with the temptation he will also provide the way of escape, that you may be able to endure it.

•Colossians 2:8- Beware lest anyone cheat you through philosophy and empty deceit, according to the tradition of men, according to the basic principles of the world, and not according to Christ.

I’ve been reading out of Acts 17 today, and the opposition that Paul and Silas faced in Thessalonica was nothing different than what we often see today in our present culture.

Paul and Silas were staying in the house of Jason while preaching the gospel and reasoning through scripture to provide truth and expose error. Some did decide to follow and chose to boldly stand along side of them. But I want you to see the rest of the town’s response to their evangelism,

•Acts 17:5-7// But the Jews who were not persuaded, becoming envious, took some of the evil men from the marketplace, and gathering a mob, set all the city in an uproar and attacked the house of Jason, and sought to bring them out to the people. But when they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some brethren to the rulers of the city, crying out, “These who have turned the world upside down have come here too. Jason has harbored them, and these are all acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying there is another king—Jesus.”

Do you know what sticks out to me? Verse 6 when they speak of Paul and Silas and say, “These who have turned the world upside down have come here too.”

I so love that. They may not have agreed with them, they may have been completely triggered by them, but there was no denying that these men were turning the world upside down for Jesus.

I don’t know about you, but that encourages me!

That’s the type of legacy I want to leave upon this earth as well.

Never moved by hostile persecution, yet forever charging toward the goal of preaching the gospel and making disciples no matter what the cost! Lord, make me bold for all the right things! 

•Proverbs 28:1- The wicked flee when no one pursues, but the righteous are bold as a lion.
